text: Here  ,  as  elsewhere  ,  the  Rom  an  conquest  is  not  immediately  visible  in  the  archaeological  record  .
label: Time Period

text: The  `  romanised  '  material  presumably  arrived  on  the  site  from  the  third  quarter  of  the  1st  century  onwards  ,  so  that  a  number  of  groups  contained  fabrics  of  both  `  unromanised  '  and  `  romanised  '  groups  .
label: Time Period

text: Only  two  very  small  context  groups  did  not  contain  sherds  of  the  `  unromanised  '  fabric  group  ,  and  one  of  these  (  3101  )  was  the  only  group  which  on  ceramic  criteria  alone  looked  as  if  it  might  have  been  later  in  date  than  the  2nd  century  AD  (  in  fact  it  was  a  topsoil  context  in  Trench  1131  )  .
label: Time Period

text: Forty-four  context  groups  were  assigned  to  the  late  Iron  Age-  Roman  period  on  ceramic  criteria  (  in  some  cases  there  may  have  been  stratigraphic  reasons  for  assigning  a  later  date  )  .
label: Time Period

text: Of  these  groups  ,  27  contained  only  sherds  in  `  unromanised  '  fabrics  and  were  therefore  broadly  dated  to  the  1st  century  AD  (  though  some  could  possibly  have  belonged  to  the  preceding  century  )  .
label: Time Period

text: Seven  groups  were  dated  late  1  st  century  or  possibly  later  ,  four  were  dated  late  1  st  century  to  2nd  century  and  five  were  assigned  entirely  to  the  2nd  century  .
label: Time Period
Time Period
Time Period

text: The  one  group  which  appeared  on  ceramic  grounds  to  be  later  has  already  been  mentioned  .
4.2  The  balance  of  evidence  therefore  indicates  a  pre-conquest  origin  for  the  site  ,  though  the  precise  date  of  this  is  uncertain  .
label: Time Period

text: The  range  of  fabrics  and  forms  present  ,  and  the  absence  of  regionally  common  fabrics  such  as  BB2  suggests  that  activity  after  the  middle  of  the  2nd  century  AD  was  very  limited  .
label: Time Period

text: 5  Context  5.1  Late  Iron  Age  and  Roman  pottery  was  recovered  from  45  contexts  (  one  ceramically  dated  to  the  post-medieval  period  )  in  14  trenches  (  1127-1135  ,  1138  ,  1139  ,  1141  ,  1144  and  1976  )  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: SH  .
SH  .

5.3  The  relationship  of  the  present  assemblage  to  the  villa  is  uncertain  in  the  sense  that  almost  none  of  the  pottery  derived  from  contexts  which  could  be  shown  to  be  contemporary  with  the  use  of  the  villa  buildings  .
label: Artefact

text: The  material  from  the  trenches  which  examined  the  villa  buildings  (  Trenches  1132  and  1133  on  the  main  building  ,  and  Trenches  1128  and  1134  on  the  aisled  building  )  was  generally  from  deposits  thought  to  predate  the  structures  ,  and  in  any  case  in  Trenches  1132  and  1133  quantities  of  pottery  were  minimal  .
label: Artefact

text: Sherds  from  3220  ,  the  fill  of  a  small  pit  probably  cut  by  one  of  the  villa  wall  s  ,  were  all  in  shell-tempered  fabric  assigned  to  the  1  st  century  AD  .
label: Context
Time Period

text: The  Roman  ised  grey  wares  ,  which  suggested  a  probable  early  -  mid  2nd  century  date  ,  were  notably  small  in  comparison  with  the  earlier  (  1st  century  )  material  contained  within  the  group  .
label: Time Period
Artefact
Time Period
Time Period

text: The  significance  of  this  is  uncertain  but  the  group  was  clearly  not  homogeneous  in  its  composition  .
Pottery  from  trenches  lying  at  some  distance  from  the  structures  could  not  be  linked  with  the  structures  in  any  way  .
label: Artefact

text: 6  General  Comments  6.1  The  assemblage  is  drawn  from  sources  whose  position  in  the  regional  pattern  of  pottery  supply  ,  both  before  and  after  the  Rom  an  conquest  ,  seems  fairly  well  established  .
label: Time Period

text: The  present  material  does  not  extend  the  chronological  range  of  the  site  significantly  beyond  the  middle  of  the  2nd  century  AD  .
label: Time Period

text: This  is  broadly  consistent  with  the  evidence  from  the  more  limited  assemblage  gathered  from  the  site  in  fieldwalking  in  1994  ,  though  Canterbury  type  oxidised  sandy  ware  and  BB2  were  both  noted  there  ,  as  well  as  a  3rd  century  Oxford  mortarium  type  ,  which  might  indicate  a  slightly  later  component  in  the  assemblage  than  is  evident  in  the  present  material  .
label: Time Period
Location
Time Period
Location

text: Most  of  the  pottery  is  not  closely  associated  with  the  villa  buildings  ,  though  some  of  it  may  provide  a  terminus  post  quem  for  these  building  s  .
Stratigraphic  evidence  and  the  chronology  of  the  pottery  both  suggest  that  much  of  the  material  should  predate  the  villa  structures  .
label: Artefact

text: In  this  regard  the  association  of  tile  with  the  pot  tery  groups  is  of  interest  .
label: Artefact
Artefact

text: Rom  an  tile  ,  in  some  cases  in  reasonable  quantity  ,  occurred  in  a  total  of  18  of  the  44  context  groups  with  1  st  and  2nd  century  pottery  .
label: Time Period
Artefact

Artefact

text: Unless  there  is  a  huge  problem  with  residual  pottery  and/or  intrusive  tile  ,  it  seems  reasonable  to  take  these  associations  more  or  less  at  face  value  and  to  suggest  that  the  villa  must  have  been  in  existence  by  the  middle  of  the  2nd  century  AD  ,  was  quite  probably  there  in  the  early  2nd  century  and  could  have  originated  as  early  as  the  later  1  st  century  AD  .
label: Artefact

text: 7  Assessment  of  Potential  and  further  work  7.1  The  present  assemblage  is  of  crucial  importance  for  understanding  the  chronology  of  the  site  .

It  is  otherwise  limited  in  terms  of  potential  for  providing  data  on  trade  and  status  and  functional  aspects  of  the  site  because  of  its  small  size  ,  but  if  further  excavation  of  the  site  were  to  take  place  the  present  material  could  form  a  very  useful  part  of  any  resulting  assemblage  and  could  contribute  to  the  understanding  of  all  these  aspects  .
In  the  event  of  further  work  the  principal  requirement  would  be  to  refine  the  definition  and  recording  of  the  range  of  fabrics  present  in  the  assemblage  .

This  should  result  in  improved  understanding  of  the  sources  of  the  material  ,  and  therefore  of  such  aspects  as  trade  ,  and  should  also  lead  to  greater  precision  in  dating  both  individual  groups  and  the  development  of  the  site  as  a  whole  .

7.2  Should  there  be  no  further  work  on  the  site  it  would  still  be  necessary  to  characterise  the  fabrics  in  more  detail  than  at  present  in  order  to  maximise  the  potential  of  the  existing  material  to  inform  discussion  of  the  chronology  and  economics  of  the  site  .
Of  this  total  four  fragments  (  5.165  kg  )  ,  principally  two  bricks  from  the  structure  in  Trench  1977  ,  were  of  post-medieval  date  and  are  not  considered  further  here  .
label: Artefact
Time Period

text: The  remaining  material  (  250  fragments  ,  22.188  kg  )  was  of  Rom  an  date  .
label: Time Period

text: The  material  was  scanned  briefly  by  context  group  and  divided  into  fabrics  identified  on  characteristics  visible  to  the  naked  eye  .
Approximate  numbers  of  fragments  rapidly  assignable  to  principal  tile  types  were  also  noted  .
label: Artefact

text: 1  fragment  ,  32  g.  2.2  In  practise  there  was  a  degree  of  overlap  between  fabrics  2  and  3  ,  and  fabric  4  may  simply  have  been  a  reduced  version  of  fabric  1  .
Further  work  would  help  to  refine  these  definitions  and  confirm  their  validity  .

2.3  The  relatively  few  fragments  of  fabric  2  included  a  group  of  six  large  pieces  in  context  2712  ,  which  together  amounted  to  38.6  %  by  weight  of  the  total  tile  from  the  site  .
label: Artefact

text: Fabric  1  constituted  43.2  %  of  the  tile  by  number  but  only  18.3  %  by  weight  .
label: Artefact

text: This  is  partly  because  the  weight  figures  are  skewed  by  the  large  fragments  just  mentioned  ,  but  also  reflects  the  fact  that  both  fabrics  2  and  3  appeared  to  be  used  for  tegulae  of  significantly  above  average  thickness  ,  with  the  result  that  even  small  tegula  fragments  in  these  fabrics  tended  to  be  quite  heavy  .
label: Artefact
Artefact

text: The  sample  size  is  such  that  the  significance  of  this  should  not  be  pressed  too  far  ,  however  .

text: 4  Context  and  Dating  4.1  The  tile  derived  from  33  contexts  in  ten  trenches  (  1127-1129  ,  1131-1135  ,  1139  and  1176  )  ,  a  distribution  similar  to  but  slightly  more  limited  than  that  of  the  pottery  (  see  table  above  )  .
label: Artefact

text: The  `  white  '  tile  fabric  2  had  a  more  limited  distribution  still  (  in  Trenches  1127-  1129  ,  1134-1135  and  1176  )  ,  but  in  view  of  the  total  sample  size  this  need  not  be  particularly  significant  .

The  association  of  tile  with  the  pottery  ,  discussed  above  ,  suggests  that  most  if  not  all  of  the  material  should  be  dated  within  the  period  from  late  1st-  mid  2nd  century  .
label: Artefact
Artefact
Time Period

text: 5  Assessment  of  Potential  and  further  work  5.1  The  material  is  of  significance  in  indicating  aspects  of  the  character  of  Rom  an  structures  on  the  site  .
label: Time Period

text: The  presence  of  distinctive  fabric  types  (  fabrics  2  and  3  )  should  also  allow  assessment  of  the  sources  of  building  material  for  the  site  and  thus  provide  information  on  economic  aspects  .

The  total  quantity  of  tile  recovered  to  date  is  relatively  small  ,  and  if  no  further  work  is  undertaken  on  site  the  only  additional  examination  of  the  present  material  likely  to  be  required  would  involve  more  detailed  characterisation  and  definition  of  the  fabrics  ,  in  particular  to  determine  if  there  were  significant  differences  between  fabrics  2  and  3  ,  and  identification  of  their  probable  sources  .
label: Artefact

text: Such  work  would  clearly  also  be  required  in  the  event  of  a  larger  assemblage  being  available  for  study  ,  in  which  case  more  detailed  attention  could  also  be  given  to  tile  forms  .
label: Artefact

text: 2  Results  2.1  There  was  a  total  of  227  fragments  present  ,  of  which  36  fragments  came  from  a  partial  skeleton  of  an  adult  sheep  .
label: Species

text: This  group  is  the  only  material  in  the  assemblage  which  is  in  excellent  condition  (  1  )  .
This  good  preservation  and  the  large  size  of  the  animal  is  consistent  with  a  post-medieval  date  for  the  material  .
label: Time Period

text: 2.2  Of  the  remaining  191  fragments  ,  which  are  predominantly  in  moderate  to  poor  condition  (  condition  3-4  )  ,  only  45  were  identifiable  to  species  .
The  majority  of  these  are  fragments  of  cattle  bone  (  28  )  ,  although  fragments  of  sheep  /  goat  (  5  )  ,  pig  (  7  )  and  horse  (  4  )  also  occur  in  small  numbers  .

text: 3  Summary  3.1  Little  can  be  said  of  this  small  assemblage  as  it  stands  ;  even  the  predominance  of  cattle  fragments  may  ,  given  the  condition  of  much  of  the  bone  ,  be  partly  the  result  of  a  bias  against  the  preservation  of  the  smaller  domestic  mammals  .
label: Species

text: However  ,  the  character  of  the  material  shows  that  useful  information  may  be  gained  if  a  larger  assemblage  is  recovered  from  further  excavation  ,  particularly  since  there  appear  to  be  few  published  Late  Iron  Age  /  Early  Rom  ano-British  assemblages  of  any  size  from  Kent  .

text: 1.2  The  purpose  of  the  assessment  was  to  evaluate  the  quality  of  the  preservation  of  the  charred  material  and  the  potential  for  further  sampling  and  analytical  work  .
2  Methods  2.1  Soil  samples  were  processed  by  bulk  water  separation  and  floated  onto  a  0.5mm  mesh  .
The  material  derives  from  Gault  Clay  and  was  very  difficult  to  break  down  in  flotation  .
label: Material

text: Charred  remains  were  noted  in  the  residues  of  samples  2  and  4  .
The  residue  for  sample  4  was  therefore  re-floated  .
Flots  were  then  allowed  to  slowly  air  dry  before  being  submitted  for  assessment  .
2.2  Each  flot  was  put  through  a  stack  of  sieves  and  scanned  under  a  binocular  microscope  .
The  quantity  and  quality  of  charred  plant  material  was  noted  .
Material  was  provisionally  identified  and  estimates  were  made  of  the  abundance  of  grain  ,  chaff  ,  weed  seeds  ,  charcoal  and  other  charred  items  .
label: Artefact
Artefact
Artefact
Artefact

text: Abundance  was  recorded  on  a  three  point  scale  ,  (  +  =  1-10  items  ,  ++  =  10  -  100  ,  +++  =  >  100  items  )  .
This  information  is  tabulated  below  .
Samples  which  contained  no  charred  plant  remains  are  not  included  in  the  results  table  .
2.3  Due  to  the  problems  encountered  during  flotation  ,  the  residues  were  also  quickly  scanned  to  establish  the  quantity  of  charred  material  which  had  not  floated  .

Time Period

text: The  preservation  of  the  material  from  these  samples  is  exceptional  and  adds  to  their  intrinsic  importance  .

5.2  While  deposits  of  good  environmental  remains  may  not  be  ubiquitous  ,  the  quality  and  quantity  of  the  material  from  this  single  pit  is  sufficient  to  suggest  that  the  potential  for  useful  material  from  a  larger  scale  excavation  is  very  high  .
label: Context

text: Given  the  shortage  of  published  records  of  charred  material  from  systematically  sampled  sites  in  Kent  ,  the  potential  for  significant  information  to  be  gained  from  further  sampling  of  even  a  limited  nature  is  very  high  .
label: Location

text: On  a  Late  Iron  Age/  Roman  rural  site  such  as  this  a  range  of  features  ,  perhaps  including  wells  and  corn  dryers  might  be  expected  .
label: Time Period

text: The  potential  for  waterlogged  material  from  wells  may  exist  .
RECOMMENDATIONS  6.1  The  assessment  of  the  charred  plant  remains  from  the  evaluation  excavation  was  intended  to  serve  two  purposes  .
Firstly  to  establish  the  potential  of  the  material  in  the  samples  themselves  .
Secondly  ,  the  assessment  was  designed  to  establish  the  potential  for  further  sampling  for  charred  plant  remains  in  the  event  of  future  excavations  .
6.2  The  present  samples  do  offer  some  potential  for  detailed  analysis  in  their  own  right  .
If  no  further  excavation  and  sampling  takes  place  the  two  richer  samples  should  be  analyzed  in  full  .
The  information  gained  from  two  samples  will  ,  however  ,  be  limited  .
The  samples  have  indicated  the  potential  of  the  site  in  the  event  of  future  excavations  .
Large  scale  excavation  might  be  expected  to  expose  a  range  of  features  of  both  Iron  Age  and  Roman  date  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: It  would  be  especially  important  to  compare  the  cereal  economy  of  the  region  with  that  elsewhere  and  ,  for  example  ,  investigate  the  apparent  continuation  of  emmer  wheat  into  the  Iron  Age  ,  not  seen  elsewhere  in  southern  Britain  ,  and  examine  the  nature  and  development  of  the  environment  on  the  clay  belt  in  this  part  of  Kent  .

text: Location  ,  topography  and  geology  The  site  is  located  on  the  south  side  of  Part  Lane  ,  to  the  east  of  Riseley  (  Figs  1  ,  2  )  .
label: Location
Location

text: The  underlying  geology  is  mapped  as  Gravel  (  BGS  1946  )  and  a  patchy  clayey  gravel  was  in  fact  revealed  by  the  groundworks  .
The  site  lies  at  a  height  of  c.  49m  above  Ordnance  Datum  on  level  ground  .

Archaeological  background  The  archaeological  potential  of  the  site  stems  from  its  location  within  the  Loddon  Valley  which  is  considered  as  archaeologically  rich  with  numerous  sites  recorded  from  field  survey  and  aerial  photography  (  Ford  1994  ;  Gates  1975  )  .
label: Location

text: This  was  to  involve  examination  of  all  areas  of  topsoil  stripping  ,  landscaping  ,  ground  reduction  and  the  digging  of  trenches  for  foundations  and  services  for  structures  as  necessary  .
Results  Prior  to  the  groundworks  ,  previous  structures  on  the  site  were  demolished  .
Three  components  of  the  groundworks  were  observed  (  Fig  .
The  footings  observed  were  dug  using  a  small  360DEG-type  machine  and  measured  0.7m  wide  and  were  1.05m  deep  .
These  revealed  a  simple  stratigraphy  which  consisted  of  made  ground  to  a  depth  of  c.  0.3m  above  the  natural  clayey  gravel  (  Fig  .

Three  areas  of  modern  disturbance  (  service  trenches  and  a  brick  foundation  )  were  noted  but  no  deposits  of  archaeological  interest  were  observed  and  no  artefacts  earlier  than  the  late  19th  or  20th  centuries  were  noted  (  not  retained  )  .
label: Time Period

text: Two  rectangular  trenches  were  dug  on  the  eastern  margins  of  the  site  for  interceptor  tanks  .
These  were  in  turn  5m  x  3m  and  2m  x  2m  in  extent  and  were  dug  to  1.3m  and  1.1m  respectively  .
Apart  from  a  modern  land  drain  revealed  in  the  larger  trench  no  deposits  of  archaeological  interest  observed  .
A  small  drainage  ditch  approximately  0.5m  wide  and  0.5m  deep  was  dug  along  the  southern  limit  of  the  site  .
No  deposits  of  archaeological  interest  were  observed  .
A  garage  block  forming  part  of  the  proposal  ,  and  the  entranceway  were  to  be  constructed  using  concrete  rafts  involving  no  deep  ground  disturbance  .
Their  construction  was  not  observed  .
Conclusion  Areas  of  modern  disturbance  were  presumably  associated  with  the  previous  structures  on  the  site  .
No  deposits  nor  finds  of  archaeological  interest  were  revealed  during  the  watching  brief  .

text: INTRODUCTION  1.1  Planning  Background  Bedfordshire  County  Council  has  granted  planning  permission  (  2005/39  )  for  alterations  and  an  extension  to  form  a  new  classroom  and  music  rooms  at  Leighton  Middle  School  .
label: Location
Location

text: Given  the  archaeological  sensitivity  of  the  development  area  ,  a  PPG  16  para  .
30  condition  was  attached  to  the  planning  permission  .
The  County  Archaeological  Officer  (  CAO  )  advised  that  the  site  of  the  new  classroom  should  be  subject  to  a  programme  of  strip  ,  map  and  sample  .
While  the  music  rooms  ,  which  were  in  an  area  of  greater  modern  disturbance  ,  should  be  subject  to  a  programme  of  observation  and  recording  .
label: Time Period

text: Albion  were  commissioned  to  undertake  the  strip  ,  map  and  sample  works  on  10th  April  2006  .
label: Time Period

text: This  document  is  a  report  on  the  results  of  those  works  .
The  programme  of  observation  on  the  Music  Room  was  not  necessary  as  this  stage  of  construction  has  not  taken  place  .
1.2  Site  Location  and  Description  Leighton  Middle  School  lies  at  the  western  end  of  the  historic  core  of  Leighton  Buzzard  within  the  town  centre  Conservation  Area  .
label: Location
Location

text: It  is  bounded  by  Bridge  Street  to  the  north  and  Church  Square  to  the  east  .
label: Location
Location

text: The  development  works  are  adjacent  to  existing  school  buildings  .
The  site  of  the  new  classroom  is  centred  on  SP  9186  2497  and  has  a  footprint  of  c.70sqm  (  Figure  1  )  .
1.3  Archaeological  Background  The  archaeological  background  to  the  town  of  Leighton  Buzzard  is  summarised  in  the  Extensive  Urban  Survey  (  Albion  Archaeology  2005  )  .
label: Location
Time Period

text: The  school  lies  within  what  was  probably  the  late  Saxon  settlement  core  ,  and  certainly  the  medieval  settlement  core  (  HER  16871  )  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: It  is  close  to  the  bridge  over  the  River  Ouzel  ,  which  is  first  documented  in  the  14th  century  .
label: Location
Time Period

text: The  original  crossing  point  would  clearly  be  much  older  .
The  site  of  the  new  classroom  lies  immediately  to  the  north  of  the  site  of  the  prebendal  mansion  .

This  was  an  important  element  in  the  town  from  at  least  the  late  12th  century  ,  when  Leighton  was  made  into  a  prebendal  stall  ,  right  up  to  the  19th  century  ,  when  the  latest  house  was  demolished  .
label: Time Period
Location
Time Period

text: The  prebendal  mansion  was  no  doubt  rebuilt  several  times  before  its  final  demolition  .
A  surviving  painting  depicts  the  position  of  the  post-medieval  mansion  and  associated  buildings  and  gardens  in  relation  to  the  church  .
label: Time Period

text: Structural  remains  ,  in  the  form  of  infilled  cellars  ,  have  been  encountered  by  excavation  within  the  western  part  of  the  churchyard  .
The  site  of  the  new  classroom  probably  lies  just  beyond  a  series  of  gardens  laid  out  to  the  north  of  the  mansion  itself  .
OBJECTIVES  AND  METHODOLOGY  2.1  Introduction  The  programme  of  archaeological  observation  was  undertaken  on  several  different  dates  between  April  12th  and  April  26th  2006  .
label: Time Period

text: During  this  period  all  excavations  which  required  monitoring  were  completed  .
A  mechanical  excavator  was  used  to  open  the  footing  trenches  .
2.2  Methodology  The  observation  works  adhered  to  the  standards  and  field  methods  set  out  in  Albion  Archaeology  's  Procedures  Manual  (  Albion  Archaeology  2000  )  .
label: Time Period

text: In  summary  :  1  Any  stripping  of  overburden  and  excavation  of  footing/service  trenches  was  monitored  to  try  to  identify  in  situ  archaeological  deposits  .
2  All  disturbed  soil  was  scanned  for  artefacts  .
3  Any  excavated  features  and  deposits  were  fully  recorded  in  accordance  with  Albion  's  Procedures  Manual  .
4  All  archaeological  observations  were  recorded  at  a  suitable  scale  on  base  plans  that  were  tied  in  to  the  Ordnance  Survey  national  grid  .
5  A  photographic  record  was  kept  of  all  significant  features  .

Throughout  the  project  the  standards  set  out  in  the  Institute  of  Field  Archaeologists  Codes  of  Conduct  and  Standards  and  Guidance  documents  (  specifically  Standard  and  Guidance  for  an  Archaeological  Watching  Brief  ,  September  1999  )  and  in  English  Heritage  's  Management  of  Archaeological  Projects  (  1991  )  were  adhered  to  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: 2.3  Objectives  The  overall  objective  of  the  archaeological  works  outlined  in  the  Project  Design  (  Albion  Archaeology  2006  )  was  to  fully  define  ,  investigate  and  record  any  archaeological  deposits  which  would  be  destroyed  in  the  course  of  the  development  .
label: Time Period

text: It  was  considered  possible  that  remains  revealed  within  the  development  area  would  shed  light  on  the  early  development  of  the  town  in  the  vicinity  of  the  River  Ouzel  crossing  .
label: Location

text: The  development  of  urban  centres  from  the  late  Saxon  period  to  the  present-day  has  been  identified  as  a  regional  research  priority  (  Glazebrook  1997  ,  59-64  ;  Brown  and  Glazebrook  2000  ,  27-32  ,  45  )  .
label: Time Period
Time Period
Time Period
Time Period

text: Although  the  footprint  of  the  building  work  was  relatively  small  ,  it  was  clearly  in  an  area  of  high  archaeological  potential  .
The  specific  aims  of  the  investigation  were  to  :  i  .
Establish  the  date  ,  nature  and  extent  of  activity  or  occupation  in  the  development  areas  ;  ii  .
Establish  the  relationship  of  any  remains  found  to  the  surrounding  contemporary  landscapes  ;  iii  .
Recover  artefacts  to  assist  in  the  development  of  type  series  within  the  region  ;  iv  .
Recover  palaeo-environmental  remains  to  determine  local  environmental  conditions  .

RESULTS  3.1  Introduction  The  new  classroom  comprised  three  phases  of  groundworks  ,  these  were  recorded  as  three  different  trenches  (  Figure  2  )  ,  as  follows  :  o  Trench  1  -  Footprint  of  sunken  floor  level  for  new  classroom  A  15.50m  by  7.85m  trench  was  excavated  to  a  maximum  depth  of  1.10m  over  the  entire  footprint  of  the  new  classroom  .
o  Trench  2  -  Footing  trenches  for  new  classroom  Three  footings  trenches  were  excavated  within  the  footprint  of  Trench  1  .
These  trenches  reached  a  further  1.00m  below  the  base  of  Trench  1  ,  meaning  the  base  was  a  maximum  of  2.10m  below  the  existing  ground  level  .
o  Trench  3  -  Soakaway  and  associated  trenches  A  soakaway  and  associated  drainage  pipes  were  excavated  to  the  west  of  Trenches  1  and  2  .
Detailed  technical  information  on  all  the  deposits  and  archaeological  features  referred  to  below  can  be  found  in  Appendix  1  .
3.2  Overburden  and  Undisturbed  Geological  Deposits  Undisturbed  geological  deposits  consisted  of  mid  orange  ,  sandy  alluvial  gravels  and  sands  .
The  topsoil  layer  was  a  dark  brown  black  sandy  silt  layer  .
This  occurred  in  relatively  undisturbed  parts  of  the  development  area  .
A  layer  of  concrete  ,  a  cobbled  surface  and  several  make  up  layers  were  recorded  within  ,  and  to  the  west  of  building  [  104  ]  (  Figure  2  )  .
These  are  thought  to  relate  to  the  construction  of  this  ,  and  possibly  other  buildings  on  or  near  this  location  during  the  late  post-medieval  and  modern  periods  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: 3.3  Post-Medieval  Remains  3.3.1  Three  N-S  aligned  ditches  (  Figure  2  )  Three  N-S  aligned  ditches  (  G  [  300  ]  ,  G  [  302  ]  ,  G  [  304  ]  )  were  stratigraphically  the  earliest  features  .
label: Time Period

text: They  run  parallel  to  each  other  and  are  thought  to  be  broadly  contemporary  .
They  mark  the  location  of  a  land  boundary  to  the  east  of  ,  and  parallel  to  ,  the  river  Ouzel  .
label: Location

text: Artefactual  material  recovered  from  these  ditches  (  Appendix  2  )  consists  of  the  remains  of  a  well  preserved  ,  articulated  horse  skeleton  .
label: Species

text: The  good  bone  condition  suggests  the  horse  was  dumped  in  the  still  partially  open  ditch  during  the  post-medieval  period  .
label: Context
Time Period

text: This  provides  further  evidence  of  a  post-medieval  origin  for  these  features  .
label: Time Period

text: 3.3.2  Pits  and  postholes  (  Figure  2  )  Five  pits  (  [  108  ]  ,  [  119  ]  ,  [  157  ]  ,  [  159  ]  ,  [  146  ]  )  and  two  postholes  (  [  125  ]  ,  [  153  ]  )  were  revealed  .
label: Context
Context
Context
Context

text: These  features  contained  dateable  artefactual  material  (  Appendix  2  )  suggesting  a  post-medieval  /  modern  date  for  their  period  of  use  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: Pit  [  146  ]  contained  a  single  sherd  of  residual  medieval  pottery  ,  suggesting  earlier  activity  in  close  proximity  .
label: Artefact
Time Period
Artefact

text: Their  function  remains  unknown  .
However  ,  pits  in  this  area  may  well  have  been  associated  with  rubbish  disposal  from  nearby  houses  .
label: Context

text: Postholes  may  be  associated  with  fence  lines  dividing  garden  plots  or  other  land  boundaries  in  this  busy  urban  context  .
label: Context

text: 3.3.3  N-S  aligned  boundary  wall  (  Figures  2  -  4  )  An  N-S  aligned  wall  [  111  ]  was  recorded  towards  the  eastern  end  of  the  development  area  .
label: Context
Context

text: The  upper  part  of  this  wall  was  constructed  from  post-medieval  ceramic  bricks  (  112  )  built  on  top  of  an  earlier  roughly  hewn  ,  sandstone  block  wall  (  124  )  .
label: Context
Time Period
Material
Artefact
Artefact
Context

text: It  is  tempting  to  see  this  lower  wall  as  substantially  earlier  .
However  ,  ceramic  bricks  were  present  in  small  numbers  within  it  ,  suggesting  the  stone  may  have  been  re-used  from  an  earlier  wall  .
label: Material
Artefact
Artefact

text: This  wall  broadly  follows  the  alignment  of  the  three  boundary  ditches  which  lay  either  side  of  it  (  Section  3.3.2  )  .
label: Context
Context

text: It  is  possible  that  one  or  more  of  the  ditches  were  open  at  the  same  time  as  this  wall  was  in  use  .
label: Context

text: The  combination  of  ditches  and  walls  ,  or  ditches  and  hedges  ,  is  often  used  to  emphasise  boundaries  .
label: Context
Context
Context

text: 3.3.4  Structure  built  against  N-S  aligned  boundary  wall  (  Figure  2  )  A  brick  built  structure  (  [  104  ]  )  was  recorded  in  the  central  northern  part  of  the  development  area  .

Material

text: The  base  of  this  wall  was  recorded  during  the  works  .
This  wall  butted  against  wall  [  111  ]  (  Section  3.3.3  )  which  formed  its  eastern  side  .
label: Context
Context

text: Wall  [  104  ]  truncated  make  up  layers  which  sealed  ditches  G  [  300  ]  and  G  [  302  ]  .

Artefact

text: 3.4  Undated  Remains  3.4.1  Pits  and  postholes  (  Figure  2  )  Posthole  [  148  ]  ,  pits  [  168  ]  and  [  162  ]  /  [  164  ]  contained  no  dateable  artefactual  material  .

Context
Context

text: Despite  this  they  are  most  likely  to  date  to  the  post-medieval  period  and  may  have  served  a  similar  purpose  to  the  pits  and  postholes  described  in  Section  3.3.2  .

text: 3.4.2  Tree-throws  and  features  of  natural  origin  (  Figure  2  )  A  tree-throw  [  166  ]  and  a  small  circular  rooting  depression  [  115  ]  were  also  identified  within  the  study  area  .
SYNTHESIS  4.1  Interpretation  A  series  of  N-S  aligned  boundary  features  (  comprising  a  wall  and  three  ditches  )  were  recorded  .
label: Context
Context

text: Building  material  within  the  wall  and  artefactual  remains  recovered  from  one  of  the  ditches  confirm  a  post-medieval  date  is  likely  for  all  of  these  features  .
label: Context
Context
Time Period

text: They  represent  the  presence  of  a  land  boundary  running  parallel  with  the  river  Ouzel  (  c.  150m  west  )  and  also  located  a  short  distance  from  the  High  Street  (  c.  50m  north-east  )  and  immediately  north  of  the  site  of  a  prebendal  mansion  (  Section  1.3  )  .
label: Location
Location

text: Other  remains  comprised  broadly  contemporary  (  post-medieval  )  pits  ,  postholes  ,  cobbled  surfaces  and  make-up  layers  .
label: Time Period
Context
Context

text: A  minor  structure  was  built  up  against  the  large  N-S  wall  (  above  )  and  truncated  the  three  N-S  ditches  demonstrating  that  at  least  some  changes/developments  in  land-use  had  occurred  during  the  late  postmedieval  /  modern  period  .
label: Context
Context
Time Period
Time Period

text: Given  the  proximity  of  this  land  to  the  historic  High  Street  ,  it  is  to  be  expected  that  it  would  contain  remains  dating  to  these  periods  .
label: Location

text: It  served  as  backyard  land  during  the  post-medieval  and  modern  periods  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: Such  land  (  especially  close  to  rivers  )  is  often  used  for  the  excavation  of  wells  ,  disposal  of  rubbish  in  pits  etc  .
label: Context

text: The  presence  of  minor  fences  dividing  land  and  the  presence  of  cobbled  surfaces  or  minor  lanes  would  also  be  typical  .
The  remains  recorded  at  Leighton  Middle  School  fit  easily  into  this  pattern  of  land-use  and  are  all  thought  to  be  broadly  contemporary  .
label: Location

text: Little  earlier  evidence  relating  to  the  development  of  this  historic  town  was  present  .
In  particular  ,  no  evidence  relating  to  early  roads  (  perhaps  leading  to  a  bridge  over  the  Ouzel  )  was  found  .
label: Location

text: 4.2  Significance  The  remains  encountered  at  the  site  are  of  local  significance  .
They  comprise  the  remains  of  several  stages  in  the  use  and  development  of  late  post-medieval  /  modern  backyards  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: The  land  lies  a  short  distance  south  of  an  important  post-medieval  /  modern  road  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: This  was  lined  with  houses  and  business  premises  making  the  development  area  an  ideal  location  for  backyard  activities  such  as  garden  plots  and  rubbish  disposal  areas  .
These  remains  have  successfully  been  tied  in  with  historical  map  evidence  confirming  the  likely  character  of  this  area  during  the  late  post-medieval  /  modern  period  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: One  sherd  of  medieval  pottery  was  recovered  from  a  post-medieval  pit  ,  suggesting  that  the  remains  of  earlier  activity  may  have  been  destroyed  by  later  truncation  .
label: Artefact

2003/46  Summary  An  archaeological  evaluation  and  watching  brief  was  carried  out  at  land  between  Highcross  Street  and  Vaughan  Way  ,  Abbey  Ward  ,  Leicester  (  SK  5831  0459  )  by  the  University  of  Leicester  Archaeological  Services  (  ULAS  )  between  22/01/03  and  27/02/03  for  Hallams  Contacts  Ltd.  in  advance  of  a  proposed  hotel  and  casino  development  .
label: Location
Location
Location
Location
Location

text: The  area  was  stripped  in  phases  and  revealed  early  Roman  deposits  comprising  dump  layers  relating  to  the  1st-2nd  century  Roman  townhouse  ,  which  had  been  discovered  on  the  site  in  1958  .
label: Time Period
Time Period
Time Period

text: These  layers  provided  levelling  for  the  3rd  century  Macellum  ,  or  Market  Hall  complex  .
label: Time Period

text: The  Macellum  remains  consisted  of  walls  and  floor  deposits  ,  confirming  the  layout  recorded  by  J.  S.  Wacher  during  earlier  excavations  and  revealing  an  extension  of  the  building  to  the  north  ,  with  a  series  of  wall  and  robber  deposits  indicating  further  rooms  existing  at  right  angles  to  Wacher  's  main  building  .
The  northern  extension  appeared  to  comprise  a  central  aisle  ,  flanked  by  rooms  on  either  side  .
The  central  aisle  contained  a  stone  structure  at  the  southern  end  ,  which  may  have  been  the  base  for  a  statue  .

Evidence  for  remains  post-dating  the  Macellum  were  also  encountered  and  include  a  collapsed  roof  and  fire  destruction  deposits  ,  found  to  contain  2nd  and  3rd  century  pottery  sherds  .
label: Time Period
Artefact

text: Medieval  backyard  activity  was  observed  in  the  area  ,  comprising  backyard  soils  ,  possible  structural  remains  ,  pitting  and  boundary  walls  ,  running  at  right  angles  to  Highcross  Street  .
label: Location

text: There  is  evidence  to  suggest  that  Roman  walls  may  have  been  standing  together  with  medieval  buildings  during  the  12th-13th  centuries  .
label: Time Period
Time Period
Time Period

text: Remains  of  the  medieval  Blue  Boar  Lane  were  located  ,  running  south-east  to  north-west  across  site  ,  in  addition  to  walls  relating  to  the  Admiral  Rodney  and  Blue  Boar  public  houses  .
label: Time Period
Location
Location

text: A  notable  find  from  the  excavations  was  an  intaglio  ,  depicting  Britannia  carrying  a  shield  ,  which  was  found  in  Roman  dump  deposit  (  574  )  .
label: Artefact
Time Period

text: Finds  and  archive  will  be  deposited  with  Leicester  City  Museums  Service  ,  Accession  No  .
label: Location

text: 2003  Introduction  Planning  permission  was  sought  from  Leicester  City  Council  to  construct  a  hotel  and  casino  development  on  land  at  Highcross  Street  and  Vaughan  Way  ,  Abbey  Ward  ,  Leicester  (  SK  5831  0459  ;  Reference  no  .
label: Location
Location

text: 2001/1702  )  A  stage  of  archaeological  evaluation  was  requested  by  the  Senior  Planning  Archaeologist  at  Leicester  City  Council  ,  following  work  carried  out  by  John  Samuels  Archaeological  Consultants  in  November  2001  .
label: Location
Time Period

text: (  c  )  ULAS  Report  No  .

Location  and  Geology  The  site  is  located  between  Vaughan  Way  (  Southgates  Underpass  )  and  Highcross  Street  ,  approximately  100m  to  the  north  of  St  Nicholas  Place  (  figures  1  and  2  )  .
label: Location
Location
Location
Location

text: The  site  was  owned  by  Sowden  Group  Ltd  ,  and  comprises  an  area  of  land  some  0.37ha  .
in  area  (  c.  0.95  acres  )  .
The  site  lies  at  c.  63.1m  aOD  ,  and  is  situated  on  drift  deposits  ,  comprising  the  Soar  river  gravel  terrace  over  the  solid  Mercian  Mudstone  .
label: Location
Location

text: A  substantial  depth  (  c.  3.5-4.0m  )  of  made  ground  of  both  archaeological  and  more  recent  origin  lie  over  these  natural  deposits  .

Archaeological  and  Historical  Background  The  Roman  Period  (  figure  3  )  Initial  urban  occupation  in  Leicester  can  be  dated  to  the  late  first  century  BC  ,  consisting  of  Iron  Age  settlement  occupying  an  area  of  c.  1  0ha  on  the  east  bank  of  the  river  Soar  .
label: Time Period
Location
Time Period
Time Period
Location

text: After  the  Conquest  ,  there  is  limited  evidence  to  suggest  that  a  small  fortlet  was  established  to  control  the  crossing  point  of  the  river  near  the  present  West  Bridge  (  Clay  and  Pollard  1994  ,  46  )  .
label: Location
Time Period

text: Evidence  for  timber  buildings  of  the  preFlavian  period  has  been  encountered  ,  with  the  suggestion  ,  on  the  basis  of  uniformity  of  alignment  ,  that  they  have  more  in  common  with  buildings  within  a  fort  than  with  a  native  settlement  or  vicus  .
label: Material
Time Period

text: Timber  buildings  later  in  the  first  century  are  on  a  different  alignment  ,  and  are  considered  to  represent  the  first  Roman  town  ,  expanding  to  the  east  from  the  river  ,  with  the  presence  of  wall  plaster  and  opus  signinum  suggesting  the  gradual  adoption  of  Roman  tastes  .
label: Material
Time Period
Time Period
Artefact
Artefact
Time Period

text: Ditches  from  the  Little  Lane  excavation  (  Lucas  and  Buckley  forthcoming  )  perhaps  point  to  field  systems  beyond  the  settled  area  .
label: Context
Location

text: In  the  early  second  century  ,  the  street  grid  appears  to  have  been  formalised  ,  if  not  entirely  laid  out  ,  and  at  the  same  time  ,  Ratae  was  probably  established  as  a  civitas  capital  .
label: Time Period
Location

text: Timber  buildings  of  this  period  are  aligned  on  the  street  grid  ,  and  have  been  found  beneath  the  northern  and  eastern  defences  ,  pointing  to  the  rapid  expansion  of  settlement  (  Buckley  and  Lucas  1987  )  .
label: Material
Time Period

text: In  the  middle  and  later  years  of  the  second  century  ,  a  major  programme  of  public  and  private  building  was  undertaken  .
label: Time Period

text: This  included  the  construction  of  the  forum  and  basilica  complex  ,  the  Jewry  Wall  public  baths  ,  at  least  one  temple  and  a  variety  of  domestic  ,  commercial  and  industrial  premises  (  Clay  and  Mellor  1985  ;  Clay  and  Pollard  1994  )  .
label: Location
Time Period
Time Period

text: On  most  Roman  sites  in  the  town  ,  masonry  buildings  begin  to  appear  in  this  period  ,  some  perhaps  commercial  and  domestic  properties  whilst  others  might  be  described  as  palatial  town  houses  .
label: Time Period

text: The  Forum  (  LC  45  )  was  essentially  a  large  open  square  enclosed  on  three  sides  by  colonnades  containing  shops  and  on  the  fourth  ,  northern  side  ,  by  the  Basilica  ,  a  large  aisled  building  .
The  east  and  west  colonnades  contained  a  single  row  of  shops  ,  with  two  present  in  the  southern  colonnade  .
Although  its  prime  function  was  as  a  market  place  ,  the  Forum  would  have  also  been  used  as  a  central  place  for  public  assembly  .
(  c  )  ULAS  Report  No  .
As  finally  constructed  ,  the  Forum  measured  some  131.98m  x  90.83m  .
The  large  columns  used  in  the  structure  were  made  of  millstone  grit  ,  spaced  c.  3  .3m  apart  and  resting  on  large  stylobate  blocks  (  Buckley  2000  )  .
label: Material
Time Period

text: The  northern  part  of  the  Forum  and  part  of  the  Basilica  lie  to  the  south  of  the  development  area  .
This  part  of  the  Basilica  would  represent  the  northern  face  of  the  building  ,  and  is  likely  to  have  comprised  a  colonnaded  portico  .
Nothing  is  known  of  the  internal  arrangement  .
Many  millstone  grit  columns  have  been  found  in  the  vicinity  ,  which  may  have  originated  from  the  Forum  and  Basilica  .
label: Material

text: In  the  late  second  or  early  third  century  ,  the  town  was  defended  with  a  rampart  and  ditch  ,  a  wall  perhaps  being  added  later  in  the  third  century  (  Buckley  and  Lucas  1987  )  .

text: The  Roman  Town  House  A  Roman  town  house  with  two  mosaic  floors  and  very  ornate  painted  plaster  walls  was  excavated  in  Leicester  in  1958  (  TLAHS  1959  )  .
label: Time Period
Time Period
Location
Time Period

text: It  was  located  to  the  west  of  the  development  area  and  may  encroach  upon  the  present  development  area  .

Antiquarian  records  ,  from  as  early  as  c  .  1675  ,  note  the  presence  of  the  Roman  mosaic  known  as  the  Cyparrisus  Pavement  `  against  the  elm  trees  near  All  Saints  Church  '  at  a  depth  of  c.  1  .4m  below  the  then  ground  surface  .
label: Time Period
Time Period
Species
Location

text: This  may  originally  have  lain  within  the  site  boundary  .
This  mosaic  ,  (  SMR  ref  .
LC1047  )  is  of  particular  importance  as  it  is  only  the  second  example  of  a  true  figured  mosaic  from  the  midlands  .
label: Location

text: The  date  of  the  mosaic  is  unclear  ,  although  it  may  be  of  fourth  century  date  (  Johnson  1980  )  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: Archaeological  evidence  suggests  that  at  least  one  other  Roman  town  house  existed  within  the  site  boundary  .
label: Time Period

text: Mosaics  ,  tessellated  pavements  and  the  remains  of  walls  have  been  previously  found  in  cellared  areas  of  the  site  ,  as  well  as  in  the  area  directly  to  the  north  ,  belonging  to  part  of  the  same  insula  .
By  the  end  of  the  second  century  the  Blue  Boar  Lane  townhouse  had  fallen  into  disrepair  .
label: Location

text: Soon  after  this  the  house  was  levelled  to  make  way  for  a  much  larger  structure  ,  with  a  number  of  massive  walls  (  TLAHS  1959  )  .

The  partial  excavation  of  this  structure  led  to  its  interpretation  by  the  excavator  John  Wacher  ,  as  a  Macellum  (  market  place  )  and  appears  to  indicate  the  growing  prosperity  of  the  Roman  town  and  the  need  for  two  markets  .
label: Time Period

text: Lengths  of  substantial  walling  previously  found  directly  to  the  south  of  the  Stibbe  site  (  Meek  2001  )  have  been  interpreted  as  belonging  to  the  Macellum  ,  due  to  their  size  and  their  location  within  the  same  insula  .
label: Time Period

text: (  c  )  ULAS  Report  No  .

A  possible  decline  in  urban  occupation  and  public  order  has  been  indicated  ,  with  street  metalling  having  been  dug  into  (  Redcross  Street  :  Clay  and  Pollard  1994  ,  48  )  ,  as  well  as  evidence  for  the  illegal  extraction  of  silver  from  coinage  within  the  ruins  of  the  Macellum  (  Wacher  1974  ,  353  )  .

text: Leicester  became  a  Mercian  bishopric  soon  after  670  ,  one  of  the  five  Boroughs  of  the  Danelaw  in  877  and  -  based  on  the  Domesday  Survey  -  was  apparently  a  flourishing  town  at  the  time  of  the  Norman  Conquest  ,  with  322  houses  ,  65  burgesses  and  six  churches  (  Ellis  1976  ,  p.38-9  )  .

label: Time Period

text: After  the  Conquest  ,  a  motte  and  bailey  castle  was  constructed  in  c.  1068  at  the  southwest  angle  of  the  Roman  defences  ,  in  a  position  where  it  would  dominate  the  town  .

text: As  the  population  of  the  town  increased  ,  so  did  the  demand  for  properties  on  the  main  street  frontages  .
Due  to  lack  of  available  frontage  space  ,  the  rear  yards  were  infilled  with  more  housing  and  walkways  created  to  gain  access  from  the  street  .

Although  this  became  far  more  widespread  in  the  post-medieval  period  ,  evidence  has  been  recorded  of  earlier  examples  ,  to  the  rear  of  Highcross  Street  in  the  area  of  St  .  Nicholas  Place  (  Meek  2000  ;  Buckley  2000  )  .

text: Background  At  the  time  that  ULAS  became  involved  in  the  project  ,  planning  permission  had  been  granted  by  Leicester  City  Council  for  the  construction  of  a  Travelodge  and  Casino  ,  with  the  strict  condition  requiring  the  implementation  of  a  scheme  of  archaeological  investigation  before  the  commencement  of  the  development  .
label: Location

text: At  this  stage  ,  unusually  ,  no  prior  archaeological  evaluation  of  the  site  had  been  required  before  determination  of  the  application  ,  although  after  demolition  the  site  had  been  subject  to  inspection  by  John  Samuels  Archaeological  Consultants  .

In  order  to  determine  the  most  appropriate  mitigation  strategy  for  the  archaeology  on  the  site  ,  an  assessment  was  undertaken  to  determine  the  potential  impact  of  foundations  upon  buried  archaeological  remains  .
The  building  was  to  be  constructed  with  ground-bearing  slab  ,  hence  there  was  some  potential  for  the  preservation  of  important  remains  ,  in  situ  .

In  order  to  determine  the  depth  ,  significance  and  character  of  buried  archaeological  remains  which  might  exist  between  the  deep  cellars  which  existed  on  the  site  ,  the  strategy  adopted  was  to  strip  large  areas  down  to  the  top  of  archaeology  in  order  that  these  could  be  cleaned  ,  recorded  and  sample  excavated  ,  and  a  safe  working  level  for  the  proposed  foundation  could  be  determined  .

A  number  of  foundation  options  were  explored  by  the  structural  engineer  ,  including  vibrocompaction  ,  but  in  the  event  the  archaeology  was  covered  with  geo-textile  membrane  and  the  ground  was  made  up  with  crushed  stone  ,  suitably  compacted  to  support  the  floor  slab  .
Hence  the  majority  of  the  archaeology  on  the  site  was  preserved  in  situ  ,  (  c  )  ULAS  Report  No  .

Elsewhere  on  the  site  ,  damage  from  the  pile  for  a  crane  base  and  from  service  trenches  was  mitigated  by  archaeological  watching  brief  and  salvage  excavations  during  development  .

Aims  The  aims  of  the  evaluation  and  watching  brief  programme  were  :  o  To  establish  the  nature  ,  character  and  extent  of  any  archaeological  deposits  within  the  area  affected  by  the  proposed  development  .
o  To  establish  a  date  range  (  where  possible  )  for  any  archaeological  deposits  located  .
o  To  assess  the  local  ,  regional  and  national  importance  of  any  deposits  .
o  To  locate  areas  of  archaeological  activity  accurately  in  order  to  define  an  appropriate  strategy  for  the  protection  or  excavation  of  archaeological  deposits  .
Methodology  Excavation  The  area  of  development  was  completely  stripped  of  modern  deposits  using  a  360DEG  tracked  excavator  fitted  with  a  1.6m  wide  ditching  bucket  .

It  was  decided  that  where  possible  ,  non-invasive  building  techniques  were  to  be  employed  in  the  construction  of  the  casino  ,  therefore  excavation  was  kept  to  a  minimum  and  recording  of  deposits  in  plan  and  section  became  the  main  aim  .
During  the  initial  phase  of  machining  ,  areas  A  to  J  were  stripped  to  the  top  of  archaeology  and  recorded  .
Later  work  involved  the  further  stripping  of  areas  Q-Z  ,  some  of  which  had  already  been  revealed  during  the  earlier  phase  of  machining  (  figure  8  )  .
Some  of  this  later  work  concerned  the  recording  of  archaeological  deposits  revealed  during  the  digging  of  drains  .
The  limitations  of  this  part  of  the  work  are  mentioned  below  .

In  order  to  minimise  the  destruction  of  archaeological  deposits  a  piling  and  rafting  construction  method  was  adopted  ;  this  meant  destruction  was  limited  to  the  areas  were  the  piles  were  situated  .

Damage  to  archaeological  deposits  was  greater  in  area  G  where  the  crane  base  was  situated  and  in  areas  Q  ,  X  ,  Y  and  Z  where  the  foul  and  storm  drains  were  excavated  .

Close  liaison  between  the  contractor  ,  ULAS  and  Richard  Clarke  was  maintained  to  ensure  that  damage  was  kept  to  a  strict  minimum  and  ,  where  possible  ,  alternative  strategies  were  employed  .
The  contractors  employed  a  cut  and  fill  method  to  excavate  the  drains  using  a  drag  box  .
This  method  proved  to  be  the  safest  as  the  width  and  depth  of  the  trenches  meant  contractors  would  have  been  at  great  risk  when  installing  shoring  .

As  a  result  the  recording  of  archaeological  deposits  was  very  difficult  and  most  information  gleaned  from  these  areas  comes  from  measured  sketches  ,  descriptions  and  photographs  .
Height  measurements  were  estimated  from  the  top  of  the  nearest  manhole  cover  .
(  c  )  ULAS  Report  No  .
In  some  cases  ,  however  ,  it  was  possible  to  recognise  stratified  deposits  in  section  ,  which  were  associated  with  in  situ  pottery  sherds  .
label: Artefact

text: Obvious  stratigraphical  relationships  in  plan  and  profile  were  used  as  a  relative  dating  method  and  `  obvious  '  structures  such  as  Roman  walls  ,  medieval  pits  and  late  /  postmedieval  pits  were  separated  in  order  to  construct  a  likely  matrix  for  the  site  .
label: Time Period

text: Recording  All  areas  were  recorded  using  a  Topcon  GTS-212  Electronic  Distance  Measurer  linked  to  a  Psion  hand  held  data  logger  .
Hand  drawn  plans  and  sections  were  also  used  and  are  included  in  the  archive  together  with  monochrome  negatives  and  colour  slides  .

This  stage  of  archaeological  work  was  tied  to  a  height  of  62.51m  OD  ,  which  was  located  within  the  development  area  and  was  tied  to  a  grid  provided  by  the  site  surveyor  Richard  Barker  .
The  work  followed  the  Institute  of  Field  Archaeologists  (  IFA  )  Standard  and  Guidance  for  Archaeological  Watching  Briefs  .

Results  of  the  Archaeological  Investigation  Early  activity-  1st  to  2nd  century  AD  The  deepest  recorded  Roman  deposits  were  found  in  area  G  (  figure  9  )  ,  where  a  Victorian  sewage  pipe  was  removed  ,  revealing  a  possible  pit  cut  through  a  layer  of  demolition  .

text: The  top  of  the  section  lay  at  61.14m  OD  to  the  north  and  60.60m  OD  to  the  south  .

text: Layer  491  appeared  to  be  a  make-up  or  levelling  layer  ,  consisting  of  mid-greyish  brown  clayey  silt  .
It  also  contained  large  stone  ,  slate  and  mortar  fragments  suggesting  earlier  demolition  or  wall  -collapse  ,  which  was  incorporated  into  the  levelling  up  layer  .
label: Artefact

text: A  similar  layer  (  490  )  was  seen  in  plan  to  the  west  of  this  context  and  comprised  mid-greyish  brown  ,  clayey-sandy  silt  ,  containing  occasional  small  rounded  pebbles  ,  charcoal  flecks  and  painted  wall  plaster  .
A  sherd  of  pottery  dating  from  the  late  1st  to  the  early  2nd-century  AD  was  recovered  from  this  context  ,  confirming  a  pre-  Macellum  date  for  the  layer  .

text: 4.4.6  The  first  floor  of  the  south-west  end  is  divided  into  seven  rooms  (  F2-8  )  by  modern  partition  walls  forming  a  flat  (  Fig  10  )  .
All  of  the  rooms  are  finished  with  plaster  and  wallpaper  and  have  carpets  or  vinyl  flooring  .
Room  F2  is  the  living  room  ,  and  has  a  modern  gas  fire  with  an  antique-effect  iron  surround  in  the  north-east  elevation  (  Plate  23  )  .

The  flat  plasterboard  ceiling  is  supported  by  two  beams  ,  one  of  which  is  in  situ  and  the  other  a  later  insertion  ,  although  it  is  evidently  a  re-used  timber  of  similar  type  .
The  in  situ  beam  is  bolted  at  the  south-east  end  to  a  timber  above  and  the  inserted  beam  also  has  bolt  holes  ,  presumably  fixing  it  to  the  ceiling  .
Both  also  have  a  number  of  Baltic  timber  marks  (  Plates  24  and  25  )  ,  appear  to  have  been  distressed  ,  and  been  given  a  `  rustic  '  chamfer  .
Room  F3  is  a  kitchen  ,  and  the  walls  are  largely  covered  by  modern  units  .
Like  Room  F2  ,  there  are  two  beams  supporting  the  ceiling  ,  one  original  and  one  inserted  ,  but  both  similar  timbers  .
There  is  a  step  up  into  Room  F4  ,  which  is  a  corridor  narrow  L-shaped  corridor  connecting  the  remaining  rooms  at  the  south-west  end  .
It  is  plain  ,  although  there  is  a  boxed  beam  running  from  it  into  Room  F6  .
Room  F5  is  a  bathroom  ,  and  is  finished  with  tiles  as  well  as  wallpaper  ,  and  has  numerous  modern  fittings  throughout  .
Room  F6  is  a  bedroom  with  fitted  units  and  a  boxed  beam  orientated  south-east/north-west  .
Room  F7  is  a  smaller  bedroom  ,  with  a  walk-in  cupboar  d  in  the  north-east  corner  and  a  window  in  the  south-west  elevation  with  a  wide  timber  sill  .
Room  F8  is  another  small  bedroom  with  fitted  units  ,  which  also  has  a  window  in  the  south-west  elevation  with  a  wide  timber  sill  .
label: Material

text: 4.4.7  The  roof  space  above  the  first  floor  of  the  south-west  end  of  Building  B  is  divided  into  two  parts  by  an  inserted  concrete  block  wall  and  with  an  inserted  row  of  joists  supporting  the  ceiling  below  and  fibre  glass  insulation  .
label: Material
Material

text: The  lower  part  of  the  north-west  wall  is  rendered  .

The  north-east  end  has  two  simple  trusses  comprising  overlapping  principal  rafters  (  Plate  26  )  ,  each  held  by  a  single  peg  and  with  the  punched  carpenter  's  marks  `  I  '  and  `  II  '  from  north-east  to  south-west  (  Fig  12  )  .
The  scar  of  a  narrow  collar  that  was  nailed  to  the  principal  rafters  is  also  visible  .

There  is  a  single  purlin  per  pitch  plus  a  ridge  purlin  and  attached  to  the  purlin  on  the  south-east  side  are  two  pieces  of  chamfered  timber  with  a  bolt  running  between  them  ,  which  presumably  acted  as  a  hoist  of  some  description  (  Plate  27  )  .
label: Artefact

text: The  south-west  end  of  the  roof  space  is  essentially  the  same  .
On  the  north-east  side  there  are  two  adjacent  inserted  trusses  .
In  each  case  their  form  is  similar  to  the  original  trusses  ,  but  the  principal  rafters  are  bolted  together  and  the  purlin  s  butt  each  other  at  this  point  .
At  the  south-west  end  there  is  another  original  truss  with  the  punched  carpenter  's  mark  `  III  '  .
A  later  collar  has  also  been  bolted  across  it  and  the  north-western  principal  rafter  has  Baltic  timber  marks  on  its  south-west  face  (  Plate  28  )  .
label: Location

text: All  of  the  original  timbers  in  the  roof  space  are  saw-pit  cut  ,  although  the  ridge  purlins  are  less  well  finished  .
label: Artefact

text: The  south-west  wall  of  the  south-west  half  of  the  roof  space  is  whitewashed  .
4.4.3  Building  D  :  this  comprises  a  single  room  with  a  concrete  floor  (  Plate  29  ;  Fig  17  )  .

text: Discussion  The  archaeological  condition  on  planning  permission  has  been  fulfilled  for  this  section  of  the  development  through  the  preservation  by  record  of  various  upstanding  historic  structures  off  Highweek  Street  and  Back  Road  ,  Newton  Abbot  .
label: Location
Location
Location

text: The  appearance  at  the  time  of  recording  reflected  the  amount  of  change  that  cartographic  evidence  had  shown  to  have  occurred  in  the  fabric  since  erection  of  the  various  structures  .

This  took  the  form  of  scars  and  rebuilds  ,  particularly  in  relation  to  Structures  2  and  3  where  they  could  often  be  linked  to  changes  in  the  arrangement  in  plan  shown  on  the  various  maps  .
label: Context

text: It  was  unfortunate  that  recording  of  the  fabric  was  seldom  able  to  refine  the  dating  deduced  from  consideration  of  the  maps  and  surveys  .
It  was  particularly  galling  that  Structure  1  ,  the  least  altered  of  the  three  recorded  ,  could  not  be  dated  .
label: Context

text: This  is  depicted  on  the  1842  Tithe  Map  (  Fig.4  )  and  may  well  be  shown  on  the  early  19  `  h-  century  survey  (  Fig  .

This  leat  served  Sherborne  Mill  which  is  known  to  have  been  in  existence  by  the  14  `  ``  century  (  Weddell  1985  ,  78  )  .

text: A  third  possibility  is  that  Structure  3  may  have  formed  part  of  an  abbatoir  with  cattle  and  other  stock  penned  overnight  prior  to  slaughter  .
label: Context
Species

text: Newton  Abbot  supported  several  butchers  and  this  location  would  have  been  convenient  for  supplying  hides  to  the  adjacent  tannery  .
label: Location

text: Such  premises  are  seldom  listed  in  street  directories  ,  particularly  if  owned  by  butchers  with  shops  elsewhere  in  the  town  (  AIL  in  prep  )  .

As  a  result  of  past  renovation  ,  salvage  ,  stripping  and  partial  demolition  it  has  proved  difficult  to  present  a  building  sequence  and  almost  impossible  to  identify  the  original  functions  and  subsequent  uses  of  the  structures  on  the  site  .
label: Context

text: This  is  due  ,  at  least  in  part  ,  to  the  ubiquity  of  the  building  materials  and  the  utilitarian  nature  of  the  construction  methods  .
label: Artefact

text: Such  basic  buildings  located  in  areas  neither  wholly  residential  ,  commercial  nor  industrial  ,  could  be  easily  adapted  over  time  to  suit  a  wide  range  of  functions  .
label: Context

text: It  is  these  qualities  of  simplicity  and  easy  conversion  ,  together  with  their  ubiquity  ,  which  has  allowed  these  classes  of  structure  to  pass  almost  unrecorded  and  the  structures  which  concern  this  report  achieved  recognition  largely  through  their  survival  as  many  similar  buildings  in  the  surrounding  area  were  swept  away  .
label: Context
Context

text: Greater  understanding  of  this  class  of  building  will  be  generated  only  through  more  recording  and  further  research  .
label: Context

text: The  Old  Slaughterhouse  .
WATCHING  BRIEFREPORT  2.3  Archaeological  Background  Several  archaeological  investigations  have  already  been  undertaken  on  the  site  .
The  results  ,  which  are  summarised  below  ,  have  been  taken  from  information  provided  by  John  Samuels  Archaeological  Consultants  and  previous  work  by  AOC  Archaeology  .
The  first  phase  of  work  carried  out  was  an  evaluation  by  Newham  Museum  Service  in  May  1995  .
label: Time Period

text: The  evaluation  was  undertaken  ahead  of  tree  planting  along  the  northern  edge  of  the  site  to  act  as  screening  during  the  extraction  work  .
Three  of  the  eight  trenches  revealed  prehistoric  ,  Roman  and  medieval  linear  features  .
label: Time Period
Time Period
Time Period
Context

text: &  #  61623  ;  A  fieldwalking  survey  was  undertaken  by  Essex  County  Council  Field  Archaeology  Group  in  August  1996  .
label: Location
Time Period

text: The  entire  site  was  walked  and  revealed  finds  from  the  prehistoric  ,  Roman  and  medieval  periods  .
label: Time Period
Time Period
Time Period

text: The  area  of  Phases  7  and  8  revealed  evidence  from  the  Bronze  Age  up  to  and  including  the  Romano  British  period  ;  although  the  concentration  of  finds  was  not  as  high  as  for  Phases  1-4  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: An  evaluation  of  the  entire  area  was  undertaken  by  John  Samuels  Archaeological  Consultants  in  March  1999  .
label: Time Period

text: Ten  trenches  and  42  test  pits  were  excavated  across  the  site  but  no  evidence  of  occupation  or  settlement  was  discovered  .
A  number  of  watching  briefs  were  subsequently  conducted  during  the  strip  of  the  phased  areas  .
The  watching  brief  carried  out  on  Phases  1  and  2  revealed  a  series  of  linear  features  and  pits  dated  to  the  Late  Iron  Age  .
label: Context
Time Period

text: Two  distinct  scatters  of  lithic  material  ,  that  were  likely  to  date  from  the  Late  Mesolithic  or  Neolithic  periods  were  recorded  (  John  Samuels  Archaeological  Consultants  ,  Interim  Report  ,  March  2001  )  .
label: Artefact

text: The  distribution  of  features  across  the  area  was  low  .
The  low  density  of  archaeology  recorded  suggests  that  this  part  of  the  site  was  peripheral  to  settlement  .
Therefore  the  greater  concentration  of  archaeology  previously  recorded  has  been  down  slope  from  the  Phase  5  and  6  area  along  the  line  of  the  stream  .

WATCHING  BRIEFREPORT  STRATEGY  3.1  Aims  of  the  Investigation  The  aims  of  the  investigation  ,  as  laid  in  the  Method  Statement  (  John  Samuels  Archaeological  Consultants  ,  2003  )  were  as  follows  :  &  #  61623  ;  To  establish  the  presence/absence  of  archaeological  remains  within  the  site  .
label: Time Period

text: &  #  61623  ;  To  determine  the  extent  ,  condition  ,  nature  ,  character  ,  quality  and  date  of  any  archaeological  remains  encountered  .
To  develop  a  site  narrative  that  seeks  to  establish  the  history  of  human  habitation  within  the  wider  landscape  context  .
3.2  Methodology  Prior  to  commencing  on  site  works  ,  a  Method  Statement  was  prepared  by  John  Samuels  Archaeological  Consultants  .

The  site  code  had  been  previously  obtained  from  the  London  Archaeological  Research  Centre  for  the  Phase  5  and  6  work  ,  this  code  was  also  used  for  Phases  7  and  8  (  SFM  02  )  .
label: Location

text: All  machine  stripping  was  carried  out  under  constant  archaeological  supervision  .
The  stripping  was  conducted  in  two  phases  .
The  first  was  the  removal  of  topsoil  and  the  second  the  subsoil  .
The  two  phases  of  stripping  were  monitored  .
All  stripping  was  conducted  using  a  tracked  360  &  #  61616  ;  machine  fitted  with  a  2.5m  wide  toothless  ditching  bucket  .
A  total  area  of  approximately  47,1  00m2  was  stripped  .

It  was  not  possible  to  operate  the  tracked  machine  beneath  overhead  power  lines  that  crossed  the  northeast  end  of  the  site  and  ,  in  agreement  with  Nick  Truckle  ,  the  English  Heritage  Archaeological  Advisor  ,  this  area  was  cleared  by  bulldozer  .
The  tracks  of  the  bulldozer  disturbed  the  ground  to  such  an  extent  that  it  was  impossible  to  observe  any  archaeological  features  (  see  Figure  3  )  .
A  full  written  record  was  maintained  for  all  deposits  and  features  encountered  during  the  watching  brief  .

Following  recommendations  from  Simon  Mortimer  ,  of  John  Samuels  Archaeological  Consultants  ,  in  consultation  with  the  English  Heritage  Archaeological  Advisor  ,  100  %  of  all  discrete  features  and  an  agreed  proportion  of  linear  features  including  the  terminals  were  hand  excavated  .
label: Context

text: These  were  given  individual  cut  and  fill  numbers  and  each  linear  feature  was  given  an  overall  feature  number  .
label: Context

text: These  will  be  referred  to  below  by  the  relevant  feature  number  .

Once  the  agreed  percentage  of  hand  excavation  had  been  completed  across  the  site  ,  and  following  consultation  by  Simon  Mortimer  with  English  Heritage  ,  the  machine  was  bought  back  on  and  linear  features  were  100  %  excavated  using  a  toothless  ditching  under  direct  archaeological  supervision  as  a  finds  retrieval  exercise  .
Sections  were  drawn  of  all  excavated  features  ,  and  features  were  planned  ,  located  and  levelled  by  EDM  survey  .
The  survey  was  tied  in  using  Havering  Aggregates  survey  stations  located  adjacent  to  the  site  entrance  .
Provision  was  made  to  carry  out  environmental  sampling  .
Black  and  white  and  colour  photographic  record  shots  were  taken  during  the  course  of  the  work  .

WATCHING  BRIEFREPORT  All  of  the  work  was  carried  out  in  line  with  Archaeological  Guidance  Paper  (  AGP  )  :  3  ,  Standards  and  Practices  in  Archaeological  Fieldwork  (  English  Heritage  June  1998  )  .
label: Time Period

text: Nick  Truckle  of  English  Heritage  (  GLAAS  )  monitored  the  work  .

Provision  was  made  for  a  post-excavation  assessment  and  proposals  for  analysis  as  detailed  in  Appendix  4  in  Management  of  Archaeological  Projects  (  English  Heritage  ,  1991  )  .
label: Time Period

text: Work  was  carried  out  to  the  standard  specified  by  the  Institute  of  Field  Archaeologists  (  1994  )  and  Archaeological  Guidance  Paper  :  5  Archaeological  Evaluation  Reports  (  guidelines  )  (  English  Heritage  London  Region  ,  June  1998  )  .
label: Time Period

text: RESULTS  4.1  Archaeology  Present  The  lowest  deposit  across  the  whole  area  was  the  natural  geological  layer  of  moderately  compacted  mid  reddish  yellowish  brown  gravel  and  sand  [  702  ]  with  lenses  of  soft  yellowish  red  sand  .
This  occurred  at  a  minimum  height  of  94.79m  OD  (  at  the  southeast  end  of  the  site  )  and  97.47m  OD  maximum  (  at  the  northwest  end  )  .
All  the  features  recorded  on  the  site  ,  were  cut  into  this  deposit  .
The  features  are  described  below  by  period  and  have  been  subdivided  into  groups  of  related  features  .
Figure  4  shows  the  basic  phasing  of  the  features  into  Bronze  Age  ,  Iron  Age  ,  prehistoric  of  unspecific  date  ,  Roman  ,  and  post-Medieval  .
label: Time Period

text: The  discussion  below  reveals  that  each  group  could  be  subdivided  into  earlier  and  later  periods  with  some  features  spanning  the  end  of  one  main  period  and  the  beginning  of  another  .
Bronze  Age  The  earliest  features  in  the  Phase  7  &  8  area  have  been  dated  to  the  Bronze  Age  .
label: Time Period

text: The  period  termed  the  Bronze  Age  spanned  an  approximate  date  range  from  2200BC  to  750BC  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: This  is  an  artificial  boundary  reflecting  a  grouping  of  artefact  types  ,  structural  forms  and  land  use  patterns  that  generally  occur  during  this  period  but  have  origins  in  the  preceding  Neolithic  phase  and  echoes  in  the  subsequent  Iron  Age  .
label: Time Period

text: A  concentration  of  discrete  features  was  recorded  in  the  central  part  of  the  stripped  area  .

The  most  prominent  of  these  was  a  very  large  pit  ,  2.40m  in  diameter  ,  containing  approximately  350  sherds  of  Late  Bronze  Age  pottery  up  to  200mm  in  diameter  and  800g  of  fire  cracked  flint  (  see  Figure  6  )  .

text: This  wide  cut  [  734  ]  had  gradually  sloping  sides  ,  slightly  steeper  and  deeper  on  the  northeast  side  (  0.56m  )  compared  to  the  southeast  side  (  0.42m  )  ,  with  a  gradual  curve  to  an  almost  flat  base  .
Both  upper  [  732  ]  and  middle  [  733  ]  fills  contained  fragments  of  Late  Bronze  Age  pot  ,  possibly  from  the  same  vessel  .

text: The  lowest  ,  primary  fill  [  827  ]  was  mixed  reddish  yellow  sand  and  light  grey  sandy  clay  .

Overlying  [  827  ]  was  a  layer  of  firm  mottled  light  grey  and  light  reddish  yellow  ,  clayey  sand  and  silty  sand  [  733  ]  ;  fairly  similar  to  [  827  ]  but  with  less  sand  and  more  clay  .
Sealing  the  whole  pit  was  the  tertiary  fill  [  732  ]  :  firm  mid  brownish  grey  ,  slightly  clayey  sandy  silt  with  frequent  charcoal  flecks  .
label: Context
Artefact

text: The  interfaces  between  each  fill  were  fairly  diffuse  .

All  layers  may  have  been  part  of  the  same  infilling  process  with  slight  variations  in  the  content  of  the  deposit  and  some  slumping  of  the  natural  sand  at  the  sides  of  the  pit  .
label: Context

text: The  pit  was  backfilled  with  very  specific  domestic  debris  with  at  least  300  of  the  350  pottery  sherds  being  from  the  same  vessel  .

text: To  hypothesise  that  the  pit  had  a  ritual  purpose  is  to  assume  that  ritual  and  practical  matters  were  separate  spheres  in  the  Bronze  Age  .
label: Context
Time Period

text: It  was  possible  that  they  considered  it  necessary  to  maintain  a  relationship  with  the  land  in  a  process  of  give  and  return  .
Failing  that  the  harvest  would  be  poor  ,  the  people  would  be  undernourished  and  less  able  to  tend  the  land  effectively  and  so  the  cycle  would  continue  .
Alternatively  this  pit  could  have  been  directly  associated  with  a  specific  incident  ,  hence  one  pot  .
label: Context

Vaughan-Williams  Introduction  Five  bulk  samples  were  taken  from  the  site  of  Southall  Farm  ,  Rainham  ,  for  assessment  of  archaeobotanical  remains  .
label: Location

text: They  were  sampled  from  the  fills  of  pits  ,  and  were  thought  to  be  Bronze  Age  and/  or  Iron  Age  in  date  .
label: Context
Time Period
Time Period

text: Preservation  was  of  an  average  standard  ,  and  occurred  through  the  process  of  charring  .
Most  of  the  samples  also  contained  some  modern  material  .
40  litres  of  sediment  were  taken  for  to  ,  and  6  litres  for  .

The  purpose  of  this  assessment  is  to  ascertain  the  potential  of  the  assemblages  to  provide  information  relating  to  the  activities  leading  up  to  the  dumping  of  material  ;  to  obtain  evidence  relating  to  diet  and  agriculture  ;  and  to  reconstruct  the  local  environment  .
Methodology  The  whole  of  and  10  litre  sub-samples  from  ,  ,  and  were  processed  by  flotation  by  staff  at  AOC  Archaeology  using  1mm  and  300mm  mesh  sieves  .
The  residues  were  sorted  by  eye  at  AOC  to  retrieve  artefactual  and  unfloated  environmental  material  .
The  flots  and  sorted  residues  were  scanned  by  the  author  using  a  low  power  zoom-stereo  microscope  .

Recommendation  for  further  analysis  is  based  on  the  density  ,  diversity  and  quality  of  the  material  in  combination  with  the  relevance  of  the  context  to  site  investigations  .
The  results  are  summarised  in  Table  1  .

Abstract  The  desk-based  assessment  and  building  recording  survey  of  St  .  George  's  School  ,  Northampton  found  that  the  school  had  been  built  by  the  Borough  of  Northampton  and  was  opened  in  June  1908  .
label: Location
Location
Time Period

text: Whilst  having  undergone  many  superficial  changes  ,  the  school  comprising  a  long  range  housing  junior  boys  and  girls  and  a  separate  building  for  the  infants  ,  remains  largely  as  built  .
label: Context
Context

text: Separate  covered  play  areas  and  a  toilet  block  also  survive  .
label: Context
Context

text: The  school  closed  in  1970  and  has  been  used  recently  by  Northampton  College  .
label: Context
Time Period
Location

text: It  is  to  be  demolished  in  the  summer  of  2005  .
label: Time Period

text: INTRODUCTION  1.1  St  .  George  's  School  ,  Barrack  Road  ,  Northampton  is  to  be  demolished  prior  to  the  construction  on  the  same  site  of  a  new  school  building  (  Fig  1  ,  NGR  SP  613753  )  .
label: Location
Context

text: Although  the  buildings  are  not  listed  ,  they  are  of  significant  architectural  interest  within  the  town  and  therefore  a  condition  has  been  applied  to  the  consent  for  the  development  of  the  site  requiring  that  the  buildings  were  recorded  (  Stevens  and  Ballinger  2003/2004  )  .
label: Context
Context
Time Period

text: 1.2  The  objectives  of  the  brief  were  to  :  Preserve  by  record  a  building  which  is  to  be  demolished  Provide  a  written  ,  drawn  and  photographic  record  of  St  .  George  's  School  Provide  an  understanding  of  the  development  ,  use  and  function  of  the  school  buildings  Place  the  St.  George  's  buildings  within  the  context  of  educational  provision  in  the  19th  and  early  20th  centuries  1.3  The  building  recording  survey  was  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  specifications  laid  out  in  the  RCHME  's  Recording  Historic  Buildings  ;  A  Descriptive  Specification  1996  .
label: Context
Location
Context
Context
Time Period
Time Period

text: The  recording  requested  corresponds  broadly  to  level  3  .
1.4  The  desk-based  assessment  and  site  survey  were  carried  out  in  early  May  2005  .
label: Time Period

text: This  work  was  carried  out  for  Galliford  Try  .
DESK-BASED  ASSESSMENT  2.1  Until  the  late  nineteenth  century  ,  the  provision  of  local  education  in  Northampton  was  poor  in  relation  to  the  rest  of  the  country  .
label: Time Period
Location

text: In  the  eighteenth  century  many  children  attended  Dame  schools  to  learn  the  basics  of  reading  and  writing  ,  but  this  cost  between  2d/3d  a  week  which  excluded  the  poor  .
label: Time Period

text: Bye-laws  had  been  introduced  for  the  compulsory  attendance  of  five  to  twelve  year  old  children  in  the  mid  nineteenth  century  ,  but  by  1876  it  only  affected  50  %  of  the  population  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: The  1880  Mundella  Act  empowered  School  Boards  to  enforce  attendance  ,  but  by  1902  School  Boards  were  replaced  with  Education  Committees  ,  a  provision  of  Town  Councils  .
label: Time Period
Time Period

text: It  was  in  the  very  early  years  of  this  new  administration  of  local  education  that  St  .  George  's  School  was  built  .
label: Location

text: 2.2  Until  the  early  years  of  the  twentieth  century  ,  the  site  occupied  by  St  .  George  's  School  appears  to  have  survived  as  an  isolated  parcel  of  land  planted  with  trees  ,  probably  fruit  trees  .
label: Time Period
Location
Species
Species

text: It  was  bounded  on  the  east  by  Barrack  Road  ,  to  the  south  and  west  by  Old  St.  George  's  (  sometimes  called  St.  Sepulchre  's  )  School  and  the  rear  plots  of  housing  along  St  .  George  's  Street  and  to  the  north  by  the  Barrack  's  (  Fig  2  )  .
label: Location
